VIDEO.description: Video refers to the visual media content that GPAC can process, including encoding, decoding, and streaming of video streams.

VALUE.description: A value in GPAC refers to a specific piece of data or a parameter that can be used to configure filters or processing tasks.

SOURCE.description: In GPAC, a source is an input element that provides media data to be processed. It is typically the starting point of a media processing pipeline.

OUTPUT.description: Output in GPAC refers to the processed data that is generated after media processing, ready for storage or display.

INPUT.description: An input refers to any data fed into the GPAC processing system, including video, audio, and other multimedia streams.

STREAM.description: A stream is a sequence of media data (audio, video, etc.) that is processed by GPAC. Streams are identified by PIDs and can be multiplexed or demultiplexed.

TRACK.description: A track in GPAC is a sequence of media data, such as audio or video, within a media file. Tracks are managed and processed individually.

PID.description: PID stands for Packet Identifier. It is used in GPAC to uniquely identify different streams within a media file, such as audio, video, and subtitles.

SEGMENT.description: A segment in GPAC is a portion of a media file that is delivered in chunks, particularly in adaptive streaming protocols like DASH and HLS.

PACKET.description: Packets are units of data transmitted over a network or stored in a media file. In GPAC, packets are processed to extract media streams.

DASH.description: DASH stands for Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP, a technique that enables high-quality streaming of media content over the internet.

FRAME.description: A frame is a single image in a sequence of images that make up a video. GPAC processes frames during video encoding and decoding.

SAMPLE.description: A sample in GPAC refers to a discrete unit of audio or video data. Samples are processed to reconstruct media streams.

SESSION.description: A session in GPAC is a context for managing the lifecycle of media processing tasks, including loading, configuring, and executing filters.

UINT.description: UINT stands for unsigned integer, a data type used in GPAC for various numerical parameters and properties.

MPEG.description: MPEG stands for Moving Picture Experts Group, a working group that sets standards for audio and video compression and transmission.

OPTION.description: Options in GPAC are parameters that configure the behavior of filters and processing tasks. They can be set to customize media processing.

PROPERTY.description: Properties in GPAC refer to attributes of media streams or filters, such as resolution, bitrate, and codec type, that affect processing.

SCENE.description: Scene in GPAC refers to a multimedia presentation, including video, audio, and interactive elements, typically described using BIFS or X3D.

GRAPH.description: A graph in GPAC represents the entire media processing workflow, consisting of nodes (filters) and edges (connections) that define data flow.

RESOLUTION.description: Resolution in GPAC refers to the dimensions of a video frame, typically given as width x height in pixels.

MPD.description: MPD stands for Media Presentation Description, a file that provides metadata about the media content in a DASH session.

BOX.description: A box in GPAC refers to a container or structure within a media file format, such as an MP4 box, used to store metadata and media data.

PATCH.description: A patch in GPAC refers to an update or modification to the software to fix issues or add new features.

PLAYLIST.description: A playlist in GPAC refers to a list of media files or segments to be played in a specific order, often used in streaming protocols.

MP4.description: MP4 is a standardized multimedia file format for storing video, audio, subtitles, and still images. It is widely used for streaming and media storage.

RAW.description: Raw in GPAC refers to uncompressed media data that has not been processed or encoded.

GROUP.description: A group in GPAC refers to a collection of related items, such as tracks or filters, that are processed or managed together.

PROFILE.description: A profile in GPAC refers to a set of predefined settings or configurations for media processing tasks, such as encoding profiles.

SECOND.description: Second is a unit of time used in GPAC for measuring durations and timestamps in media processing.

XML.description: XML stands for eXtensible Markup Language, used in GPAC for storing and exchanging metadata and configuration settings.

LIST.description: A list in GPAC refers to a collection of items, such as media files or filters, that are processed sequentially or in parallel.

SERVER.description: A server in GPAC refers to a software or hardware system that delivers media content over a network to clients.

WRITEGEN.description: WriteGen in GPAC context refers to a generic writing function or process used to output media data to a file or stream.

LIVE.description: Live in GPAC refers to real-time media streaming, where content is delivered to viewers as it is being generated or recorded.

STR.description: STR in GPAC stands for string, a data type used for text parameters and properties.

TILE.description: A tile in GPAC refers to a rectangular section of a video frame, used in tiling and parallel processing of video content.

HEVC.description: HEVC stands for High Efficiency Video Coding, a video compression standard designed as a successor to AVC (H.264).

CHAIN.description: A chain in GPAC is a sequence of connected filters that process media data in a specific order. Chains define the processing pipeline.

LINE.description: Line in GPAC context refers to a line of code, command, or a sequence of text in a configuration file.

HLS.description: HLS stands for HTTP Live Streaming, a media streaming protocol developed by Apple Inc. for delivering live and on-demand content.

BIT.description: A bit is the smallest unit of data in computing, representing a binary value of 0 or 1.

IMAGE.description: An image in GPAC refers to still visual media content that can be processed, encoded, and included in multimedia presentations.

INFO.description: Info in GPAC context refers to metadata or information about media content, such as duration, resolution, and codec details.

PLAYBACK.description: Playback in GPAC refers to the process of playing media content, including video, audio, and interactive elements.

AVC.description: AVC stands for Advanced Video Coding, also known as H.264, a widely used video compression standard.

INTEGER.description: An integer in GPAC is a data type used for numerical parameters and properties that do not have fractional parts.

PIPE.description: A pipe in GPAC refers to a method of inter-process communication that allows data to flow from one process to another.

DISABLE.description: Disable in GPAC context refers to the action of turning off a specific feature or function.

DUMP.description: Dump in GPAC refers to the process of outputting raw media data to a file for debugging or analysis.

ISOBMFF.description: ISOBMFF stands for ISO Base Media File Format, a file format that forms the basis for many other file formats, such as MP4 and MOV.

BITSTREAM.description: A bitstream in GPAC refers to a sequence of bits representing encoded media data, such as video or audio streams.

DESCRIPTION.description: A description in GPAC refers to text that explains the details or functionality of a media file, filter, or processing task.

DESTINATION.description: Destination in GPAC refers to the output target for processed media data, such as a file, stream, or display.

SEQUENCE.description: A sequence in GPAC refers to an ordered series of media frames, samples, or packets processed as a unit.

DECODER.description: A decoder in GPAC is a software or hardware tool that converts encoded media data back into its original format.

ITEM.description: An item in GPAC refers to an individual element or component within a media file, such as a track or segment.

TEXTURE.description: Texture in GPAC refers to a bitmap image applied to a surface in 3D graphics, used in scene descriptions and visual effects.

CODE.description: Code in GPAC context refers to programming instructions that define the functionality of filters and processing tasks.

GENERATE.description: Generate in GPAC refers to the process of creating media content or metadata, such as generating a playlist or manifest file.

PATH.description: Path in GPAC refers to the location of a file or directory in the filesystem, used to specify input and output destinations.

PERIOD.description: A period in GPAC refers to a time segment within a media presentation, often used in DASH for segmenting content.

MANIFEST.description: A manifest in GPAC refers to a file that provides information about the structure and components of a multimedia presentation.

RANGE.description: Range in GPAC refers to a span of values, such as time or byte ranges, used to specify segments or portions of media data.

RESULT.description: Result in GPAC refers to the output or outcome of a processing task or command, such as a generated file or a log message.

BUFFER.description: A buffer in GPAC refers to a temporary storage area for media data during processing or playback to ensure smooth operation.

RATE.description: Rate in GPAC refers to the speed at which media data is processed or played back, such as frame rate or bit rate.

REFRAMER.description: A reframer in GPAC adjusts the timing and structure of media frames to meet specific requirements, such as alignment for streaming.

ORDER.description: Order in GPAC refers to the sequence or arrangement of media data or processing tasks, such as frame order or filter order.

COLOR.description: Color in GPAC refers to the visual attribute of media content, including color spaces, color formats, and color adjustments.

HTML.description: HTML stands for Hypertext Markup Language, used in GPAC for web-based media presentations and interactive content.

AAC.description: AAC stands for Advanced Audio Coding, a standardized, lossy compression and encoding scheme for digital audio.

SIMPLE.description: Simple in GPAC context refers to straightforward or basic configurations and tasks that do not require complex settings.

POINT.description: Point in GPAC refers to a specific location in time or space within media data or a multimedia scene.

ACCESS.description: Access in GPAC refers to the ability to retrieve or modify media data, often involving permissions or authentication.

REPRESENTATION.description: Representation in GPAC refers to a specific version or quality level of media content, used in adaptive streaming protocols like DASH.

NOTE.description: Note in GPAC context refers to a comment or annotation added to the documentation or metadata to provide additional information.

REMOVE.description: Remove in GPAC refers to the action of deleting or excluding specific media data, elements, or configurations.

RTP.description: RTP stands for Real-time Transport Protocol, used for delivering audio and video over IP networks in real-time applications.

ENCODER.description: An encoder in GPAC is a software or hardware tool that converts raw media data into a compressed format using codecs.

COMPOSITOR.description: A compositor in GPAC is a tool that combines multiple visual elements into a single scene or output, used for video and graphics processing.

PROCESS.description: Process in GPAC refers to the series of actions or steps taken to transform or handle media data, such as encoding, decoding, or streaming.

RATIO.description: Ratio in GPAC refers to the proportional relationship between two quantities, such as aspect ratio in video frames.

REGULAR.description: Regular in GPAC context refers to standard or typical configurations and operations that follow established patterns.

FFMPEG.description: FFmpeg is a free and open-source project consisting of a vast software suite of libraries and programs for handling video, audio, and other multimedia files and streams.

ASPECT.description: Aspect in GPAC refers to the ratio of width to height in video frames, known as aspect ratio.

USER.description: User in GPAC refers to the individual or system interacting with the software, including setting configurations and running processing tasks.

DASHER.description: Dasher in GPAC is a tool or filter used to create DASH segments from media files for adaptive streaming.

PIXEL.description: A pixel is the smallest unit of a digital image or display, representing a single point of color.

INDEX.description: Index in GPAC refers to a reference point or list used to locate specific data within media files or streams.

LOCAL.description: Local in GPAC refers to files or resources that are stored on the same system where the software is running, as opposed to remote resources.

VERSION.description: Version in GPAC refers to a specific iteration or release of the software, indicating its development stage and feature set.

BIFS.description: BIFS stands for Binary Format for Scenes, a binary format used to represent and encode multimedia scenes, part of the MPEG-4 standard.

OFFSET.description: Offset in GPAC refers to a value that specifies a position within a data stream or file.

CALLBACK.description: A callback in GPAC refers to a function that is called at a specific event or condition during processing, used for custom handling of data or tasks.

PLAYER.description: A player in GPAC is a tool or application used to play back media content, including video, audio, and interactive elements.

H264.description: H.264 is a widely used video compression standard, also known as AVC (Advanced Video Coding).

CONFIG.description: Config in GPAC refers to configuration settings that define how the software operates and processes media data.

SYSTEM.description: System in GPAC refers to the combination of hardware and software components used for media processing tasks.

ROUTE.description: Route in GPAC refers to the path or method by which media data is transmitted or processed, such as routing through filters.

PNG.description: PNG stands for Portable Network Graphics, a lossless image compression format supported by GPAC for image handling.

SVG.description: SVG stands for Scalable Vector Graphics, an XML-based format for vector images that GPAC supports for graphical content.

CODEC.description: A codec is a software or hardware tool that encodes or decodes media data. GPAC supports various codecs for compressing and decompressing media streams.

SPECIFIC.description: Specific in GPAC context refers to particular details or configurations that apply to certain tasks or features.

DOXYGEN.description: Doxygen in GPAC context refers to the tool used for generating documentation from annotated source code.

FRAGMENT.description: A fragment in GPAC refers to a portion of media data, such as a segment of a video stream or a piece of a media file.

DBL.description: DBL in GPAC refers to a data type for double-precision floating-point numbers, used for various numerical parameters and properties.

TEMPLATE.description: A template in GPAC refers to a predefined structure or format used for generating media files, manifests, or configurations.

BUILD.description: Build in GPAC context refers to the process of compiling and assembling the software from source code.

HEADER.description: A header in GPAC refers to metadata at the beginning of a media file or stream that provides information about its structure and content.

SIDX.description: SIDX stands for Segment Index, a table in media files that provides information about the locations and durations of segments.

EXTRACT.description: Extract in GPAC refers to the process of retrieving specific data from a media file or stream, such as extracting audio tracks.

BLOCK.description: A block in GPAC refers to a contiguous segment of data within a media file or stream, used for processing or storage.

FRAC.description: FRAC in GPAC refers to a data type for fractional numbers, used for various numerical parameters and properties.

GENERATION.description: Generation in GPAC refers to the process of creating or producing media content or metadata.

DESIRED.description: Desired in GPAC context refers to the target state or configuration for media processing tasks or settings.

DRM.description: DRM stands for Digital Rights Management, a set of technologies used to protect and manage the use of digital media content.

GLOBAL.description: Global in GPAC refers to settings or parameters that apply universally across the software or processing tasks.

BASE.description: Base in GPAC context refers to foundational or core components and settings that underlie media processing tasks.

TIMESCALE.description: Timescale in GPAC refers to the unit of time used for timestamps and durations in media files and streams.

MULTICAST.description: Multicast in GPAC refers to the transmission of media data to multiple destinations simultaneously over a network.

MEMORY.description: Memory in GPAC refers to the storage used by the software to hold media data and processing information during operation.

QUALITY.description: Quality in GPAC refers to the perceived visual and auditory fidelity of media content, often influenced by resolution, bitrate, and compression.

CUE.description: A cue in GPAC refers to a marker or point in media data used for synchronization, navigation, or triggering events.

GITHUB.description: GitHub in GPAC context refers to the platform used for hosting the source code, version control, and collaboration on the software.

API.description: API stands for Application Programming Interface, a set of tools and protocols used for building and interacting with software applications.

PAYLOAD.description: Payload in GPAC refers to the actual data carried within a packet or stream, excluding headers and metadata.

COPY.description: Copy in GPAC refers to duplicating media data from one location to another, such as copying a file or stream.

SINT.description: SINT in GPAC refers to a data type for signed integers, used for various numerical parameters and properties.

ENCRYPT.description: Encryption in GPAC refers to the process of securing media content by converting it into a code to prevent unauthorized access. GPAC supports various encryption standards like CENC and ISMA.

MOVIE.description: A movie in GPAC refers to a multimedia presentation that includes video, audio, and other media elements.

TSI.description: TSI in GPAC context refers to a Time-Stamping Interface, used for synchronizing and managing timestamps in media streams.

SINK.description: A sink in GPAC is an output element that receives processed media data. It is usually the endpoint of a media processing pipeline.

LATENCY.description: Latency in GPAC refers to the delay between the input and output of media data during processing or transmission.

DEPTH.description: Depth in GPAC refers to the color depth or bit depth of media content, affecting the range of colors that can be displayed.

ISO.description: ISO stands for International Organization for Standardization, which develops and publishes international standards, including media file formats.

UNSIGNED.description: Unsigned in GPAC refers to numerical data types that can only represent non-negative values.

ATTRIBUTE.description: An attribute in GPAC refers to a property or characteristic of a media file, filter, or processing task.

BOXES.description: Boxes in GPAC refer to container structures within a media file format, used to store metadata and media data.

SIGNAL.description: Signal in GPAC refers to a transmission of data, such as an audio or video signal, within a media processing pipeline.

PCM.description: PCM stands for Pulse Code Modulation, a method used to digitally represent analog signals, commonly used for audio.

OPENGL.description: OpenGL stands for Open Graphics Library, a cross-language, cross-platform API for rendering 2D and 3D vector graphics.

UPDATE.description: Update in GPAC refers to the action of applying changes or modifications to the software or media files.

INIT.description: Init in GPAC refers to the initialization process where settings and parameters are configured at the start of media processing.

XMT.description: XMT stands for Extensible MPEG-4 Textual format, used for describing MPEG-4 scenes in a textual format.

OFFSCREEN.description: Offscreen in GPAC refers to rendering graphics or processing media content outside of the visible display area.

SCHEME.description: A scheme in GPAC refers to a specific method or protocol used for processing or transmitting media data.

SAP.description: SAP stands for Stream Access Point, a marker in media streams that allows for efficient seeking and synchronization.

RFRAWVID.description: RFRAWVID in GPAC context refers to raw video data in radio frequency format, used in specific media processing tasks.

SUB.description: Sub in GPAC refers to subtitle data that can be processed and displayed along with video content.

CENC.description: CENC stands for Common Encryption, a standard for encrypting media content to ensure secure and interoperable streaming.

APPLY.description: Apply in GPAC context refers to the action of executing a specific configuration or processing task.

ALPHA.description: Alpha in GPAC refers to the transparency level of a visual element, used in video and graphics processing.

MULTI.description: Multi in GPAC refers to multiple instances or elements, such as multiple tracks, filters, or streams processed together.

STORE.description: Store in GPAC refers to saving media data or settings to a file or persistent storage.

SUBTITLE.description: Subtitle in GPAC refers to textual information displayed along with video content, providing dialogue or descriptions.

STORED.description: Stored in GPAC refers to media data or settings that have been saved to a file or persistent storage.

TTML.description: TTML stands for Timed Text Markup Language, a standard for representing timed text media for interchange among authoring systems.

SERVICE.description: A service in GPAC refers to a function or feature provided by the software, such as streaming or encoding services.

PARAMETER.description: A parameter in GPAC refers to a setting or value that configures the behavior of a filter or processing task.

TYPICALLY.description: Typically in GPAC context refers to common or usual configurations and operations that are frequently used.

OVERVIEW.description: Overview in GPAC refers to a summary or general description of a feature, tool, or processing task.

NODE.description: A node in GPAC refers to a point in a processing graph where media data is manipulated, such as a filter or transformation.

SHAPE.description: Shape in GPAC refers to the geometric form of a visual element, used in scene descriptions and graphics processing.

THREAD.description: A thread in GPAC refers to a separate path of execution within the software, allowing for parallel processing of tasks.

BYTE.description: A byte is a unit of data consisting of 8 bits, used in GPAC for measuring data sizes and storage.

RAP.description: RAP stands for Random Access Point, a point in a media stream where decoding can begin without needing to reference earlier frames.

SOCKET.description: A socket in GPAC refers to an endpoint for communication between devices or processes, used for network streaming and data transfer.

LOOP.description: Loop in GPAC refers to the action of repeating a sequence of media data or processing tasks.

GENERIC.description: Generic in GPAC context refers to standard or common configurations and tasks that apply to various media processing scenarios.

BINARY.description: Binary in GPAC refers to data represented in binary form, used for encoding and storing media content.

MUX.description: Mux stands for multiplexing, the process of combining multiple signals into one signal over a shared medium.

CONNECT.description: Connect in GPAC refers to establishing a link between filters or processing elements to form a media processing pipeline.

RTSP.description: RTSP stands for Real-Time Streaming Protocol, used for controlling streaming media servers.

CLOCK.description: Clock in GPAC refers to the timing mechanism used to synchronize media data during processing and playback.

CSTR.description: CSTR in GPAC context refers to a C-style string, a sequence of characters used in programming.

TRANSITION.description: Transition in GPAC refers to the visual or audio effect that occurs when moving from one scene or segment to another.

X3D.description: X3D is an XML-based format for representing 3D graphics and scenes, supported by GPAC for interactive multimedia presentations.

CACHE.description: Cache in GPAC refers to the temporary storage of media data to improve performance and reduce latency.

MODULE.description: A module in GPAC refers to a separate component or plugin that adds specific functionality to the software.

STORAGE.description: Storage in GPAC refers to the saving and managing of media data on physical or cloud-based storage systems.

TIMELINE.description: Timeline in GPAC refers to the chronological order of media events or frames, used for synchronization and editing.

FIELD.description: A field in GPAC refers to a specific area of data within a media file or metadata structure.

META.description: Meta in GPAC refers to metadata, which is information about media content, such as title, author, and duration.

ENCODE.description: Encoding in GPAC is the process of converting raw media data into a compressed format using codecs. This is essential for reducing file sizes and preparing media for streaming or storage.

TREE.description: A tree in GPAC refers to a hierarchical structure used to organize media data or processing tasks.

SEGMENTATION.description: Segmentation in GPAC refers to dividing media content into smaller segments for processing or streaming.

INITIAL.description: Initial in GPAC refers to the beginning state or configuration of a media processing task or pipeline.

SRT.description: SRT stands for SubRip Subtitle, a format for subtitle files that can be used in GPAC for adding subtitles to video content.

YUV.description: YUV is a color space used in video compression and broadcasting, representing the luminance and chrominance components of color.

DESCRIPTOR.description: A descriptor in GPAC refers to metadata that describes the characteristics or properties of media content.

MIME.description: MIME stands for Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions, a standard for describing the type of data in media files and streams.

NHML.description: NHML stands for Non-Hierarchical Meta Language, a format used in GPAC for describing complex multimedia presentations.

OPTIONAL.description: Optional in GPAC context refers to settings or parameters that are not required but can be used to customize media processing tasks.

ASSIGNED.description: Assigned in GPAC refers to the allocation of specific values or parameters to filters or media data.

DASHING.description: Dashing in GPAC refers to the process of creating DASH segments and manifests for adaptive streaming.

BITRATE.description: Bitrate in GPAC refers to the number of bits processed per unit of time, typically measured in kbps (kilobits per second).

IDENTIFIER.description: An identifier in GPAC refers to a unique name or number assigned to a media stream, track, or processing element.

DELAY.description: Delay in GPAC refers to the time lag between the input and output of media data during processing or transmission.

TIMEOUT.description: Timeout in GPAC refers to a period of time after which a processing task or connection will be terminated if no response is received.

ROOT.description: Root in GPAC refers to the top-level directory or base element in a hierarchical structure, such as a file system or processing graph.

REPLACE.description: Replace in GPAC refers to the action of substituting one media element or setting with another.

DEBUG.description: Debug in GPAC refers to the process of identifying and fixing issues in the software or media processing tasks.

PSSH.description: PSSH stands for Protection System Specific Header, a data structure used in MPEG-DASH and Common Encryption (CENC) to carry information about the content protection system.

GENERAL.description: General in GPAC context refers to standard or common features and tasks that apply to various media processing scenarios.

LIBGPAC.description: Libgpac in GPAC refers to the core library that provides the main functionality for media processing tasks.

COMMON.description: Common in GPAC context refers to features or settings that are shared across multiple media processing tasks or configurations.

SEPARATED.description: Separated in GPAC refers to the state of media data or elements being distinct and not combined.

UDP.description: UDP stands for User Datagram Protocol, a communication protocol used across the internet for time-sensitive transmissions such as video playback.

REGULATION.description: Regulation in GPAC context refers to the control and management of media data and processing tasks to meet specific standards or requirements.

MULTIPLEXER.description: A multiplexer in GPAC is a tool that combines multiple media streams into a single output, such as combining audio and video into an MP4 file.

OPT.description: Opt in GPAC context refers to optional settings or parameters that can be configured to customize media processing tasks.

MODIFY.description: Modify in GPAC refers to the action of changing or adjusting media data, settings, or configurations.

COMPLETE.description: Complete in GPAC context refers to the state of a media processing task or pipeline being finished or fully configured.

ACTIVE.description: Active in GPAC refers to filters or processing tasks that are currently running or engaged in media processing.

CHILD.description: Child in GPAC refers to a dependent element or process that is part of a larger hierarchical structure, such as a filter within a graph.

VERTICAL.description: Vertical in GPAC refers to the orientation or arrangement of media data or visual elements, particularly in video frames.

DRAW.description: Draw in GPAC refers to the action of rendering graphics or visual elements on a display.

SENT.description: Sent in GPAC refers to media data that has been transmitted or delivered to its destination.

HEIF.description: HEIF stands for High Efficiency Image File Format, a file format for individual images and image sequences.

BOUNDARY.description: Boundary in GPAC refers to the edge or limit of a media segment, frame, or processing task.

DISK.description: Disk in GPAC refers to the physical storage device used to save media data and software configurations.

ARGUMENT.description: An argument in GPAC refers to a parameter or option passed to a command or function to specify its behavior.

STOP.description: Stop in GPAC refers to the action of terminating a media processing task or playback.

CONNECTION.description: Connections in GPAC refer to the relationships between filters in a processing graph. They define how data flows from one filter to another.

STRL.description: STRL in GPAC refers to a string list, a data type used for handling multiple string values.

RGB.description: RGB stands for Red, Green, Blue, a color model used in digital imaging and video processing.

POSITIVE.description: Positive in GPAC refers to numerical values that are greater than zero, used in various settings and parameters.

INTERLEAVING.description: Interleaving in GPAC refers to the process of mixing multiple media streams in a specific order to ensure synchronized playback.

EXT.description: Ext in GPAC context refers to an extension, a file or module that adds additional functionality to the software.

NODEJS.description: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 JavaScript engine, used in GPAC for server-side scripting and media processing.

PLACE.description: Place in GPAC refers to a location within media data or a processing pipeline where specific actions are taken.

UNIT.description: Unit in GPAC refers to a standard measure used in media data, such as frames per second or bits per second.

NETWORK.description: Network in GPAC refers to the system of interconnected devices and protocols used for transmitting media data.

OVERRIDE.description: Override in GPAC refers to the action of replacing a default setting or parameter with a custom value.

DROP.description: Drop in GPAC refers to the action of discarding media data, such as frames or packets, during processing or transmission.

CHARACTER.description: Character in GPAC refers to an individual letter, number, or symbol used in text or metadata.

VRML.description: VRML stands for Virtual Reality Modeling Language, used in GPAC for describing 3D interactive graphics and scenes.

POSITION.description: Position in GPAC refers to the location of media data within a file or stream, used for navigation and editing.

SPLICE.description: Splice in GPAC refers to the action of joining two segments of media data together seamlessly.

BUILT.description: Built in GPAC context refers to the state of the software or a media processing pipeline being fully constructed and ready for use.

INTERFACE.description: An interface in GPAC refers to the point of interaction between different components or the user and the software.

CTS.description: CTS in GPAC refers to Composition Time Stamp, used for synchronizing media data during playback.

SPEED.description: Speed in GPAC refers to the rate at which media data is processed or played back, such as playback speed.

ACCORDING.description: According in GPAC context refers to actions or configurations that follow specific rules or conditions.

MASK.description: Mask in GPAC refers to a binary pattern used to select or ignore specific bits in media data or settings.

REMOTERY.description: Remotery in GPAC context refers to a tool used for profiling and analyzing the performance of media processing tasks.

CONTROL.description: Control in GPAC refers to the mechanisms and commands used to manage media processing tasks and settings.

CORE.description: Core in GPAC context refers to the essential components and functionalities of the software that provide its main capabilities.

CREATION.description: Creation in GPAC refers to the process of generating media content or metadata, such as creating an MP4 file.

PROGRAM.description: A program in GPAC refers to a sequence of instructions or tasks designed to perform specific media processing functions.

TIMESTAMP.description: A timestamp in GPAC refers to a marker indicating a specific point in time within media data, used for synchronization and navigation.

CHANNEL.description: A channel in GPAC refers to a path for transmitting media data, such as an audio channel or a data channel.

DECLARATION.description: A declaration in GPAC refers to a statement that defines settings or configurations for media processing tasks.

DIRECTIVE.description: A directive in GPAC refers to a command or instruction that guides the behavior of media processing tasks.

WEBVTT.description: WebVTT stands for Web Video Text Tracks, a format for displaying timed text tracks (such as subtitles) with HTML5 video.

GOP.description: GOP stands for Group of Pictures, a sequence of video frames used in compression standards such as MPEG.

MP4MX.description: MP4MX in GPAC context refers to MP4 multiplexing, the process of combining multiple media streams into an MP4 file.

GPU.description: GPU stands for Graphics Processing Unit, used in GPAC for hardware-accelerated processing of graphics and video.
